Mass. reports 438 new confirmed coronavirus cases, 9 new deathsThe closely watched uptick in coronavirus cases in Massachusetts continued Tuesday, as the number of confirmed cases rose by 438 — the first time the number had risen above 400 since early June — bringing the total to 111,033. The death toll from confirmed cases of the coronavirus in the state rose by nine to 8,436.
The latest COVID-19 numbers from Massachusetts
Key metrics the state is monitoring for reopening
US nears 5 million coronavirus cases

Baker warns if coronavirus cases go in wrong direction, he could slow down reopeningGovernor Charlie Baker warned Tuesday that Massachusetts may have to scale back its reopening efforts if positive coronavirus cases continue to creep up.
What would trigger a second lockdown in Mass.? The state still hasn’t laid out clear guidelines

More than 70 killed, over 3,000 injured in massive blast in BeirutA massive explosion rocked Beirut on Tuesday, flattening much of the city’s port, damaging buildings across the capital and sending a giant mushroom cloud into the sky. More than 70 people were killed and 3,000 injured, with bodies buried in the rubble, officials said.
Photos and video from the scene in Beirut, where a massive explosion rocked the Lebanese city

AnalysisJoe Biden’s running mate may matter less in 2020 than in any election in a generation. Here’s whyPresumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden has a commanding lead over President Trump in polls and it's not clear anyone he picks as his number two would change that.
Some see sexism in debate over Biden VP’s choices after commentary about demeanor

Cambridge’s police chief said the city doesn’t get ‘military equipment.’ An inventory says the department has 64 M4 riflesA statement by Police Commissioner Branville Bard Jr. set off a firestorm in Cambridge, particularly from City Councilor Quinton Zondervan, who lambasted him for peddling “not factually correct” statements. Bard stood by his statement and defended the city’s arsenal.
Boston police spent more than $200,000 on military-style equipment during first five months of this year
